title: Improving Elemental Detection In XRF Spectrum Images From Paintings By Applying Image Restoration Methods
content: Systems have been developed for non-contact scanning of large works of art by X-ray fluorescence (XRF). Such systems can collect very large datasets. The National Gallery of Art built one which can scan a painting up to 1.7 by 1.4 meters in size at a spatial resolution of 0.2 mm/pixel [1]. At one pixel per second, the resulting 60 million pixels would take about two years to acquire, so pixel dwell times are necessarily short compared to whatâ€™s customary for analytical instruments. Squeezing information from limited counts is a priority even when pixel spectra can be summed over a similar area.
